step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with a stillbirth at 35 weeks with no visible malformations and normal placenta. The next step involves determining the cause of stillbirth. While karyotyping (A) is indicated for certain anomalies, the absence of malformations may not necessitate it immediately. Autopsy (B) is a standard step to identify underlying causes, especially when no structural issues are present. The placenta being unremarkable suggests no placental pathology, but autopsy can reveal other factors. Options C and D are less directly relevant to immediate postmortem evaluation. The documents emphasize diagnostic tests and pathological evaluations (Document [2]), supporting autopsy as the next step.
